author: @neiljohnson9686
text: My problem has been wanting to run  Different programs that require specific versions of python to work. As someone who did a lot of programming 30 years ago and got back into it just a few years back I can‚Äôt believe python is not compatible with other versions of itself .And I‚Äôm not talking a Giant gap‚Ä¶ 3.10.6, versus 3.10.9.  I have to go through agony to switch from being able to run one of the programs and then the other. I‚Äôve even had one version of python basically gut the other version when I installed it even though I put it in a different directory. I have  a degree in data communications from years ago, and I just finished a degree in information technology which included a lot of programming‚Ä¶ and I just don‚Äôt understand why something that would run on 3.10.6 would not run at all on 3.10.9 that‚Äôs just crazy in my eyes. Anyway, I‚Äôm just venting lol after pulling my hair out for 10 hours‚Ä¶ Your video is awesome! Looks like I will need Venv as you mention. I tried using docker, but since I don‚Äôt have windows, professional edition, I can only make Linux Containers‚Ä¶ Well, let‚Äôs just say my last experience with UNIIX was with Berkeley BSD on an AS400 box üòÖ   I learned a lot from your video that I can put to use. Thank you.

author: @surajoberai
text: if someone getting error like "the module VIRTUALENV_NAME can't be loaded" , try the following commands:  1. Set-ExecutionPolicy -ExecutionPolicy RemoteSigned -Scope CurrentUser 2. VIRTUALENV_NAME\bin\Activate.ps1  PS:  python version is 3.10

author: @yasirzahid5088
text: in short (i am assuming you have activated virtual environment) type: pip freeze (you will see all requirements) copy all to requirements.txt (16:40 observe copying process carefully) //(make sure requirements.txt is in project folder) type: deactivate (venv will be deactivated) type: pip install -r .\requirements.txt  (all requirements will be installed) type:.\venv\Scripts\Activate.ps1  (activating environment)

text: Hi Corey.  Can I ask you a question?  (Asked Hopefully Answered by me below) I follow everything you say in your video.  I use a simple compiler "Thonny."  If I have activated my virtual environment and use Thonny to run the main.py script how do I ensure that it is only using the packages from the virtual environment?  Obviously it can be any other compiler like idle or etc.  I just need to ensure that the compiler is using the virtual environment (local) installation and not the global installation packages and files.  Hope you can help me understand this.  OK APOL.  I think I see it now.  In Thonny there is a command that allows one to log onto a virtual environment. I did this and Thonny indicates that it is using python.exe from the virtual environment folder.  (i.e. C:/Users/myname/Desktop/pythoncourse/day3/venv/Scripts/python.exe.)   I ASSUME NOW that none of the other global packages are being used?  Only local ones?

author: @gc-0377
text: Dude!, you're awesome!, thank you very much, you have  a new subscriber If you are using powershell instead of cmd and having troubles executing Scripts\activate.bat and execute it without the .bat extension still not working: Execute a powershell as administrator and type Get-ExecutionPolicy -List it gonna shows:  Scope ExecutionPolicy         ----- --------------- MachinePolicy       Undefined    UserPolicy       Undefined       Process       Undefined   CurrentUser       Undefined  LocalMachine    Undefined  then to change LocalMachine to Unrestricted type: Set-ExecutionPolicy Unrestricted and press s  **Warning, doing this you are exposing your pc to maliciousus scripts  then you can execute your evironment   Scripts\activate (withour the .bat extension)  To undo this action just open another or the same powershell as administrator and type Set-ExecutionPolicy Undefined and press s

text: Export pip list:         pip freeze > requirements.txt Import pip list:         pip install -r  "requirements.txt path" Create Env with pip packages:         python -m venv "projectName" --system-site-pakages

author: @matiasgomez9416
text: pip list > 2:13 python -m venv project_env > 2:29 project_env\Scripts\activate.bat > 3:24 where python > 3:46 pip install requests > 4:48 pip install pytz > 5:00 pip list >  pip freeze > 5:47  --> copy information 'pip freeze'  --> create requirements.txt > 6:37  --> paste information there deactivate > 7:16 rmdir project_env /s > 7:33  >> NEW PROJECT <<  mkdir my_project > 8:48 python -m venv my_project\venv > 8:55 my_project\venv\Scripts\activate.bat pip install -r requirements.txt > 9:46 cd my_project > 10:50  --> create new file 'script.py' deactivate >  rmdir venv /s > python -m venv venv --system-site-packages > 13:30 venv\Scripts\activate.bat >  pip list > pip install SQLAlchemy pip list --local
